While I personally have not run into any bugs YET I am sure I will but with that said The game is $10 (currently at time of writing) and controls real smooth and the way the shot modifiers interact with each other to where I have not seen anything not interact with others to where it seems like they looked at Binding of Isaac saw "Oh people love getting those game breaking items but also hate it because they don't synergize with anything let's try to make all the items to where they all synergize to avoid that 'oh this item is a game winner but I don't want it because nothing interacts with it'"

If the game was $20 I would wait and see if I run into any game breaking bugs, but at $10 it is super fun and well worth the cost even if later in the game there is a bug that prevents progression. The synergies are amazing and fun and who wouldn't find "oh let me equip this wand with modifiers that make my dragon laser circle me while freezing stuff and have this second wand that shoots a volley of admiditly weak but super quick shots every half a step I make to where I am constantly firing a barrage of rainbox shotgun bullets any time I am moving and able to enable a circle of death around me any time I use my equiped weapon.  The progression unlocks that rouge lites have is well balanced here to where no run feels like "oh that was a waist of time" because you are constantly getting resources to unlock new things. 

All in all Binding of Isaac is not just my most played rouge lite but a game in which I played for years and still keep going back to, and this game in it's current state feels like it will satisfy that same itch of being quick enough to where I don't feel overwhelmed with picking it up again and enjoyable enough to have some real staying power. The thing most rogue lites fail at are clunky controls or lack of staying power, and this one does not suffer from either, it controls smooth and each run feels like a different experience due to just how much synergy there is between things (not to mention the "oh I love bouncing shots but this shotgun modifier it great for my current other parts, let me just swap the bouncy bullets with shotgun ones since I have no slots, oh hey I got an upgrade where bouncy bullets are better, no problem I can just switch back" there is nothing besides inventory space that prevents you from changing up your entire build at any point during a run.

Yup. Another Roguelite, but, hey, I'm addicted to em. This one has a damned good hook, too; Every weapon (wand) has a number of slots, to equip a mix of attacks and modifiers, so you can almost always find a build that works.

It's very common for products that try to combine two classics to do a bad or mediocre job at it, because it boils down to those originals being very specific and thus not limited. This game combines Isaac and Noita, and it's less then a sum of those two. Of course, it could change, it's just the launch day in EA, and so i can only imagine and hope that devs make it good.

[h2] Art Style [/h2]
Visually this game looks uninspired and incredibly boring. First thing that comes to mind when you see every character and almost every enemy is "mobile game ad". And i can understand when such measures are used in order to quickly get the game looking like something and then do all the mechanics and gameplay, and then overhaul the visuals. But aparently it is not the case, and i will have to stare at this incredibly childish and boring artstyle for the rest of this game's life.
Sound design is just as bad, with SFX sounding like plaseholders or, again, "mobile game ad". Music is unremarkable, use of "meme" sounds feels extrimely cringy and childish. Almost everything sounds so soft and boring it feels like this is a soft room in a mental assylum and you don't remember for how long you've been there, only that every few hours you get to "enjoy" a compilation of horrible mobile game ads and cashgrab children's videos. 
Overall, unimpressed, or rather disappointed that indie games seldom come out perfect, or at least good, in every aspect. 
4/10

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
Well, let's not linger and talk about wand making. It is considerably simpler than in Noita, and i guess that won't be the case down the line when devs add more spells and wands, but the scope of what you can make seems not that big compared to Noita, simply because the mad wands in it start to become a thing once you are already 2-10 hours into a run, and here it is obviously not possible due to linear progression. Still, the lack of spells is compensated via wands being unique. In Noita, every wand aside from a few special ones is random. Here they are all premade if i understand it correctly, which makes it a bit more fun, since you don't rely on the random nature of them so much.
But random this game is. What makes you come up with incredible strategies, allowed you to "rig" the game in Isaac, EtG, StS? Most likely, it is the fact that you have a map and you can walk all over it, and/or choose where to go. This game does not have such a map structure, and in fact compared to StS you don't even know what rooms are up ahead so you can't plan, there is no room for strategizing. This makes runs feel so, so much less in your control, because the only decision you can make is the one in the room you're in. You cannot get hit by the chest or get a curse, knowing you'll be able to recover from that with items in the previous or next room. Every time you do something in this game - you take an unjustified and blind risk. And it feels much less like you're playing a roguelike and more like you're playing dice; you can sometimes choose wich path to go, and your risk is never justified because you never actually know if you'll get rid of that curse, or reroll that spell, or buy some health.
And on top of that the game is actually not really that hard. Making an OP wand is easy if you understand how to chain spells correctly; enemies don't really have some hard mechanics and killing them comes down to not getting hit, which is considerably easier than in Isaac or EtG. Bosses aren't that mechanically hard either. And so it turns out that to win in this game you need a good seed, because it determines basically everything, whether or not you get a good wand, good spells and so on. And the seed is much more important here than in other games like it because, again, you have very little control over your progression? build and path. 
7/10

But alas, it has enough content to hold you for at least 20-40 hours i presume, and it's only gonna grow and change from here, i hope. And for such a state of development, it's quite fun and well worth the price. I really hope this becomes a great roguelike, worthy of a place amongst aformentioned TBoI, Noita, EtG, StS, and it will not fail to deliver upon those inspirations.

Getting close to about 10 hours played, reached the end of what is currently available and had been enjoying it.

However, that is where the praise ends.

The game is riddled with [b]GAME BREAKING[/b] bugs. Yes it is Early Access but the [b]Major Bugs[/b] are things that should be [b]Immediately Fixed[/b]. Some bugs here and there that are annoying but dont impact gameplay are acceptable to be fixed over time in an Early Access game, but Game Breaking bugs that kill your enjoyment or desire to play are devastating.

Currently there are [b]Several[/b] bugs that impact gameplay. 

One of the worst is the [b]Inability to enter the door to progress the stage[/b]. This forces you to close out your game. When you do so, your language immediately gets set to Chinese. When trying to continue your run, it will show 3 identical copies of your save file and trying to continue will [b]Start your game as a NEW FILE[/b].

In addition, there is a [b]Constant[/b] progression bug that strips away your currencies anytime you start your file. For some reason your save file will read for example: "20x Ancient Bloods, 400x Crystal, etc" but when you enter the game you have "2x Ancient Bloods, 6x, Crystals, etc". And you [b]NEVER[/b] spent them. Your progress was just mystically deleted.

I was grinding out bosses to get the Summoner Starter Class which takes 50 Ancient Bloods, of which you get around 3 Bloods every time you beat an End of Act Boss (Not the Elite, which is the first boss fight of that level). This means you need around 17 [b]End of Act Bosses[/b] to get the class. I was at 48 Ancient Bloods, decided to exit the game by going back to the main menu, then quitting from there (to make sure it saves) and when I came back to play again, my Ancient Bloods were at [b]30[/b]. Meaning the game [b]FORCIBLY[/b] deleted 18 Bloods (which is 6 End of Act Bosses) for no reason. My 600 saved-up crystals were reduced to 16. 

This is a [b]MASSIVE[/b] issue. The entire premise of games like these is to rinse and repeat, and each time you will end up getting stronger because you can buy upgrades that will make future runs easier to take off. However, if the game has bugs that [b]Delete Progress[/b] it jeopardizes the entire game. 

Unfortunately, I will be dropping the game until I see some updates that will prevent people from losing progress, having their save files almost deleted, etc. I encourage everyone who is on the fence of buying this product to be extremely careful, and maybe wait to see if there are updates in terms of game stability and save protection.

Originally left a negative review on this game which garnered a polarizing response from the community. 31 hours with Magicraft and a few weeks post release has certainly changed my opinion about the game. I'm honestly surprised how active the devs are with releasing patches, communicating, they even added a new NPC to address feedback.  I'm honestly impressed.

Aside from Magicraft being supported by great devs and a active community, Magicraft is one of the best and underrated Roguelites I've ever played. Like HOW HASN'T THIS GAME BLOWN UP?! Anyways, the gameplay is a lite version of Noita but the game doesn't give a sh*t how OP you get and partly it's because it will absolutely destroy you if you get too wreckless. There's so many ways to modify spells using other spells, wands, relics, and upgrades. Also at the time of the review they have also added a multitude of new spells to mess around with. 

Don't come here expecting a walk in the park because this game will absolutely destroy you constantly and if you have skill issue like me, your first complete run may not come until you're 10 hours deep. After you complete the game once, you unlock Hard mode so good luck! (PS I've completed hard mode several times at this mode) but they're adding a 4th chapter sometime in the near future. I'm not sure exactly what to expect but I know it'll be amazing. The devs have stated they are adding new enemies to make Chapter 4 feel fresh.

Keep in mind this is an Early Access so this game may be drastically different by 1,0 with the balances, changes, and whatever their road map will bring. 

My only real complaint is that the training area doesn't unlock until chapter 3 which would be nice to have unlocked sooner. Either way I certainly recommend this game to any fan of the Roguelite genre.

SUMMARY: A fun wand-crafter Roguelike with a whimsical bent and plenty of interesting things to try.  Not QUITE must-buy, but close enough that if you like a good action(ish) Roguelike and coming up with insane combos, it's probably for you.

Magicraft starts with what is arguably an Isekai - some non-name guy ends up in a magical world through strange circumstances and is burdened with saving the day.  Except this means dying a lot to improve and a hope for a harem quickly dashed on the rocks of reality.  So now to try to move on with life, or afterlife, our hero ventures into magically twisted lands.

The gameplay is simple - point, shoot, vanquish monsters, chose the next room based on rewards, repeat.  But then the game elements start to interact and it gets more and more complex and interesting.

The core is wand crafting, which has three components:
* The basic wand, which has various traits and special abilities.
* The spell components you plug into it.
* The ORDER and interaction of the components which affect how the components work.

A self-casting wand that summons vampiric spiders?  Check.  How about a wand that generates enormous explosions all over that also poison enemies?  Check.  A wand that encircles you with ghostly snakes that slow enemies?  Check.  You can - and will - build all sorts of strange combinations.

You also find relics (which can upgrade) that grant various abilities, change character or wand traits, and so on.  This adds a layer of more interaction - when you blow up everything in a room, you might spawn a legion of ghosts that make short work of the survivors.

All of this is pretty easy to play, effective controls, good graphics and music.  It's a solid product, especially for Early Access.  It feels a good 80% complete, mostly needing the last level tweaked and/or a new level added and some camp content finished.

I can't QUITE call it a Must Buy - it sits on the edge of it.  It's extremely solid, evolutionary not revolutionary, so you won't see anything NEW, but what you'll see is extremely well done.  Perhaps when it leaves Early Access it will be.  But if you want a good action roguelike of wild crafting that's easy to get into, it's probably for you.

A spell combining rogue-like game.

So, it a usual rogue-like genre where you goes for a run and try to survive on the resources you rolled with. The game play is top down shooter. not exactly top, but like bird eye. You can see the videos about this. move with WASD button and shoot by aiming your mouse and left click to shoot.

The spell combining part is actually the big plus here. You are a mage, collecting wands, spells, and relics on your journey. These wands, spells, and relics will have their own effect that will give huge range of variety.

You can be a one shot wonder with one big exploding bullets, or rapid machine gun with laser, or close and personal with blade spell, or summoner that let your summons do the dirty works, and still much more.

The possibility is quite huge. Your creativity will be satisfied here. For example, there is a summoning spell that summon a pillar. A simple pillar that does nothing but blocks projectiles. there is also a spell modification that makes your spell orbiting you, and there is also a modification that connects you and your summons while damaging anything that touch these connection link. These will make you spinning a rope attached to a pillar around like a helicopter and damaging anything around you. You can put poison, and freeze to this makeshift helicopter too.

My favorite build is the blade build. where you put auto attack on other wands, and give those wands a blade spell that slashing stuff around. Put a rapid shooting spell on your main wand and those blades on other wands will triggered too. this resulting in crazy flurry of blades that erasing multiple dangerous projectiles and small critters. I won my first hard last boss with this.

Or other weird builds like invisible summoners. Like when you use a relic that put you to be invisible as long as you aren't attacking. Just let your summons and your wand guardians doing the attacks. Making you safe from many harm.

The rogue-like piece is quite deep too. Really a thought provoking. There is a summon that can do your spell. there is a spell that on impact can trigger your summon. Combine those and you can do matryoshka inception stuff. That summon can shoot a projectile that will summon something, etc etc.

And many more, like orbiting black holes, field of poisonous snakes, large freezing web of butterflies, etc.

There is also some side rooms with its own challenges and puzzles. Those are challenging enough. and you can take up more curses if you need more challenge. The puzzle is also not that boring and will take some time to be solved.

The art also good enough. Proper 2D arts for the sprites. The fire works is dazzling. your character appearance will follow your current relics. You can turn off some effect if you don't like it. You can turn down the bullet transparency if those fireworks you created filling your monitor like crazy.

The sound is still lackluster. Not that its bad, but its still need more variety so I wont get bored with the BGM. I mean, I goes thru that jungle so many time that the background sound gonna make me sick. I turn the music off and let youtube cover that part. The sound effect is still good tho.

Its also still in early access, so its till cheaper and will have more stuff to add. That, on top of the fact that there is already huge enough stuff to tinker with already.

So, yeah. For those who like rogue-like genre, and how the genre giving the best bang for your bucks, this game will give you huge amount of play time for the dollar. This game is one of the fun ones tinkering with weird combinations. You should give it a try.

It's a rather pleasant and kinda rare spell-building game, where you find and equip pieces of magic spells, that when lined up in a wand becomes a full blown magical attack!

The good thing about the game, is that it offers a wide variety of spell-types and enemies, allowing you to build complicated and fun to use attacks.
There is also a variety of bosses to fight against!

The bad things about the game, is that while there is a lot of spells to potentially make, most of the spell 'pieces' so to speak, are very minor, and only noticeable if you upgrade them, which takes a few rooms worth per spell, and some luck.
Of course, that's part of the game and intention, for the spell to be built by small pieces, but I think that even then, the pieces are too insignificant on a whole, because the wands themselves only have a few slots, and those with more slots have very crippling drawbacks like terribly slow attack-speed or ridiculously high mana cost, hindering the "fun" of it in my opinion.
Perhaps, having bigger and better wands or stronger spells would make you overpowered, but that's not hard to balance, make the enemies harder, or make a difficulty with "more complicated spells but harder foes" or similar.
There is also a personal problem I have that the characters to me, are unlikable, and I'd like the option to just silence them, and for some, alter their appearances. (Especially the maincharacter, I'm not very fond of the skins of the playable character, and the lack of option to change your gender and appearence)

Overall, game is entertaining, and I look forward to new updates!

If you like rogue likes and enjoy ARPGs, this game is for you. There is a perfect amount of simplicity, it's easy to get into, as well as complexity, tons of build mechanics to keep you engaged. Making whacky over powered builds is super fun. I sincerely hope development continues, it's already amazing as is.

The magic crafting system is very fun and allows for a lot of creativity and that's the only thing that matters when it comes to a recommendation. It's like Noita if you didn't have to worry about instantly killing yourself and ending your run every 30 seconds, and that's a huge compliment. The game's enemies are also worth mentioning in that they have fun gimmicks and their hp pools increase at an appropriately fast rate and get pretty huge pretty fast, so you actually do have to engage with said magic system to keep up, which is great.
 
As for the rest of the game, there are two main problems for me which are dialogue and sound. The dialogue isn't a deal breaker because there isn't a lot of it, but it's pretty bad and spoils the vibe of being a magical killing machine when it does come up. The bigger problem is the sound. Both the effects and music are extremely lame and generic which is the real vibe killer.

If they can afford it, the developers should really invest in some custom music tracks and try to add some spice to the sound effects because it would make the world of difference to the game's feel.

Short Version:
Nothing new in terms of gameplay or mechanics, but well put together with a lot of polish.  If you enjoy roguelikes and making spell combos I think you'll find this one worth your time and money.

Longer version:
The main gameplay loop appears done and I'm greatly enjoying it.  No bugs or crashes at all so far.  Lots of referential humor.  The potential spell/wand combos are highly varied and I've already found a few that can wipe out everything.  Combos like [spoiler]automatic minion summoning that lets me focus on dodging, clouds of poison-lightning homing butterflies, avalanches of boulders that clear projectiles, meteor storms, rainbow death rays, etc.[/spoiler]  The curses and relics are interesting even if not mechanically new and there are some combinations that can get very spicy.  The art style fits the narrative well and I'm looking forward to seeing the promised future outfits.  My congratulations to the team for great work they've done putting this together.

I want to start with saying this game is certainly fun. I love the style and the mechanics are easy to learn. The balance between randomness and choice is great. That being said I have a few complaints. The game feels fun but lacks challenge especially once you learn what works. There are some builds that are out-right broken while others are left lacking. Secondly the game is short (which they are working on.) If there was endless modes or some form of advancement past the 4th stage I would enjoy it more, especially if the game got progressively harder while restricting rewards the deeper you went. Relics are great but I would love to see greater variety in the game including some sort of viable minion build (including taunting and player shields or sharing damage). Early game minions are nice but late-game they either die too easily or do no real damage. 
Finally I do not think it is currently worth the whole 10$ price tag, maybe 7 or 8 but it needs greater variety and deeper game play first. Haven't really encountered any game-breaking bugs either.

This is a very pleasant surprise to me. I wasn't expecting of this level of quality to come out with such little fanfare. I think that with a few more additions, this game actually has the potential to rival The Binding of Isaac. 

The enemy design is good, one thing that many rogue-like games like these tend to lack is interesting enemies, there's a good variety, challenge, and unique design to them. I felt genuine fear when I saw those snake enemies, so kudos. They definitely were taking notes when they played Isaac, and did a good job at emulating some of those enemies while keeping their personal identity. There's also a Hades style progression system/room exploration. I like that there are no rooms SPECIFICALLY for your overarching progression, that's one of the worst things a game like this can do. (The awful question: "Do you doom your run now/have less fun now to get more power for future runs?) Thankfully this game gives you meaningful choices throughout, and you simply get the passive upgrade currency by beating bosses, meaning you don't need to do any 'scrap' runs. 

One of the first things I noticed was how good the game felt as well, smacking enemies with spells should be satisfying, and I'd say they accomplished that, as well as making each projectile/spell feel meaningful and meaningfully different from each other. They also did a good job with balance, as crazy as every run gets, you never feel so OP that everything is a cakewalk. I've never been to the point yet where I don't feel like I can ignore new options, and I feel constantly encouraged to FIND those game-breaking synergies because there's no definitive 'right answer' so far.

This game is the most cost-effective happiness you can buy in this terrible world.

It has a nice vibe, the magic programming part makes you wonder "how about we put this in this slot and that in that slot, does this also effect that" sort of things, and the outcomes are sometimes beyond what you can imagine. It's like a hilarious and top-down version of Notia. As you unlock more rare spells, the game becomes exponentially more exciting and funny.
The enemy design is something else. You can see some of the references that makes you smile, and yet some them them are really annoying (in a good way). My personal most hated enemy is the stone monster with one eye which smash towards you everytime your mag ball deals damage on it, it's a rare but effective design.
The 3 things I think this game stands out of the others are:

1. Really nice enemy and summons animation. Some of them makes me loosing my sanity.
2. The incredible variety of magics 
3. The chill yet humorous vibe and the dumb face of the hero.

This vibe dilutes the difficulty of the game, allowing you to constantly want to challenge deeper levels and try other combinations of magic. Many dungeon or roguelike games usually strive to create a difficult and heavy-duty vibe for players. They tend to make you feel like "I am a lone brave, constantly going deep into these harsh levels." 
But this game is different. It has a cute and chill sense of humor that makes you feel cheerful even if you die a hundred times. After all, the protagonist is just like us, a nerd who plays video games all day long, powerless to do anything else.  During the gameplay, my mentality was less like a "lonely brave" and more like a naughty student who poured active metal stolen from chemistry teacher into a random toilet seat in school and see what happens. There are shy-looking big spiders, bad-tempered rocks and very cute pop cats. Here you can study and learn the effects of magic combinations based on your own interests, and have fun doing it. It's a pure joy of exploration, and your enemies don't look that intimidating. Ok, well some of them look pretty gross, but overall they're cute.
Our real world is already so bad that the depressing and hopeless news is crushing our nerves. Why not find a little bit of pure happiness in the virtual world? I want to thank this game for being so cheap. In fact, this game is the most cost-effective happiness you can buy in this terrible world.
